msContents.summary: This palm-leaf manuscript in Bengali script, probably written around the 17th century, contains Vāmana's Kāvyālaṅkārasūtravṛtti, one of the seminal texts of Sanskrit poetics, composed in Kashmir during the reign of king Jayāpīḍa (799–813). This BnF manuscript plays a crucial role in the scholarly history of Vāmana's treatise, as Carl Cappeller (1842–1925) used it as the main witness in establishing the text for his publication of the editio princeps of the Kāvyālaṅkārasūtravṛtti, appeared in Jena in 1875.

supportDesc.foliation: Bengali numerals, left margin, preceded by śrīḥ [1–45, 47–54].

collation.desc: Main codicological unit, containing Vāmana's Kāvyālaṅkārasūtravṛtti.
One recent palm leaf, fully written in Bengali script and containing a portion of the Kālavarga of the Nāmaliṅgānuśāsana.

Two palm leaves fully written in Bengali script, but the last verso, which only has the name Vāmana and the number 237 (probably a previous shelfmark). In the recto of the last folio, the text of Vāmana's Kāvyālaṅkārasūtravṛtti starts again and continues in the penultimate folio (in the same hand).

supportDesc.condition: Relatively good state of preservation. The first two leaves are damaged with loss of text. Some damage due to humidity is found throughout, without loss of text.

layoutDesc.layout: 60 to 65 akṣaras per line. Some corrections added in the margins.
